The project was funded by a bond measure passed by California voters in November 1963 to pay for the construction of the freeway. In order to complete the project on time, the state of California was forced to borrow money from the United States Treasury, which was a risky proposition at the time. This, combined with the cost of the project, led Governor Pat Brown to declare a state of emergency in January 1965, and he called for a special session of the California Legislature to pass a bill of appropriation to cover the debt. The bill was passed in the special session, but not before it was amended to include a provision that prohibited the state from issuing bonds for the project until all construction had been completed.

Naruto Uzumaki's childhood friend and fellow genin, Shikamaru Nara, is one of the most powerful shinobi in Konoha, having fought in the Fourth Shinobi World War and been known to take on the likes of Akatsuki with little to no effort at all. Despite his power, he is a soft-spoken and kind-spirited individual, as shown when he tried to cheer Naruto up after the latter lost his chakra in a sparring match with Gaara.[1] His kindness is such that he was willing to risk his life to save Naruto from the reincarnated Susanoo, a jinchūriki that was responsible for the death of his parents and nearly killed him as a child.[2]

Personality

Shikamaru is shown to be a very kind and considerate individual, and has a good sense of justice and justice-oriented values. He cares for his friends and is willing to do whatever it takes to protect them, such as helping Naruto recover from his battle with Madara Uchiha, even going as far as to use his Sharingan to help him find the Nine-Tails' jinchūriki,

Shikamaru's abilities are based on the Shadow Imitation Technique ( 影真似の術, Kagemane no Jutsu, English TV : " Shadow Possession Jutsu " ), the signature technique of his clan, with which he merges his shadow with an opponent's shadow, making them immobilized and forced to mimic Shikamaru's movements. Background

A genin from Konohagakure, Shikamaru's dream was to become Hokage one day. He was the son of Tsunade, the Fourth Hokage, and Minato Namikaze, the Fifth and current Hokage. After graduating from the Academy, he went on to work as a medic-nin for the ANBU, but was forced to retire due to a lack of shinobi around him. When he was offered a position as one of the team leaders of Team 7, he accepted, hoping to make a difference in the war against the Akatsuki.

Personality

Shikamaru is a kind, caring individual who cares a great deal for his teammates and fellow ninja. He has a good sense of self-preservation, as shown when he tried to protect Naruto from Gaara's Shadow Imitation Technique, only to be caught in the blast.[1] Despite this, he does not hesitate to take action when it is necessary, such as his fight with Kankurō over the Sharingan's ownership and subsequent loss of the Eye of the Moon in the Land of Waves. His loyalty is strong, to the point of risking his life to protect the village

Shikamaru was born in Konohagakure, a village that was the birthplace of the Nine-Tails Jinchūriki, and his parents were killed by the beast. As a child, he spent a lot of time in the forest, learning to be stealthy and how to avoid being seen.[2] At some point in his childhood, he befriended a fox-like creature known as a tailed beast chūnin (獅子隠像, Literally meaning: "Beast Tailed Ninja" or "Tailed Beast-Ninja"), who taught him the art of stealth and ninjutsu. During the Battle of Meridian in 1864, General William Tecumseh Sherman led troops into the city, destroying the railroads in every direction, as well as an arsenal and immense storehouses ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground. Sherman is reported to have said afterwards, " Meridian, with its depots, store @-@ houses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments no longer exists. " Despite the destruction, the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired, back in operation 26 working days after the battle. Race relations remained tense during the Reconstruction era, with the riot of 1871 following a fire that damaged many businesses.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is rightly considered an architectural treasure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of the last century. Architecture students from around the nation and Canada
reference_text: are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous structures in the city having been designed by noted architects. The only home in the US south designed by noted Canadian born Architect Louis S. Curtiss, famous for inventing the glass curtain wall skyscraper, is extant on Highland Park. The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Building is generally considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and is often compared to Detroit's famed Fisher Building. Noted California Architect Wallace Neff designed a number of homes in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Black Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama State line. He had relatives in Meridian and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the area when commissions in California were lean. His work is mostly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly designed Falcon Lair, the Beverly Hills home in Benedict Canyon of Rudolph Valentino. One Neff work was lost to an expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and Verde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office structures built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Early public education in Meridian was based on the 1870 Mississippi Constitution. From 1870 to 1885, trustees appointed by the City Council served on the Board of School
reference_text: Directors, which had authority to operate the schools. Although there were several schools in the city before 1884, they were privately owned and only enrolled about 400 students. The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884. The first public school for blacks in the city was held in facilities rented from St. Paul Methodist Church. The Mississippi Legislature amended the city charter in January 1888 to allow the city to maintain its own municipal school district, and in March of the same year $ 30 @,@ 000 in bonds was approved for the city to build new public schools. From this bond, the Wechsler School was built in 1894, becoming the first brick public school building in the state built for blacks.

In the early 1900s, Meridian began a process of consolidating its school districts into one, which resulted in the creation of the Meridian School District (MSD). The MSD was the first school district in Mississippi to have a majority African-American population and, as a result, it is one of the most diverse school districts in the state.

During the 1950s and 1960s, Meridian experienced a decline in enrollment, due in part to the desegregation of public schools in Meridian and other Mississippi cities. This decline was exacerbated by economic and social factors, such as the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s and Mississippi's "Jim Crow" laws that prohibited interracial marriage and public accommodations, including restaurants, movie theaters, swimming pools, and other public facilities. These factors led to an increase in racial and socio-economic segregation in the Meridian community and contributed to the school district's failure to attract and retain high school and college students. By the mid-1970s, the enrollment had dropped to a low of 1,500 students, which was less than half of the enrollment it had been in the 1950

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is served by the Meridian @-@ Lauderdale County Public Library, located at the corner of 7th Street and 26th Avenue. The city originally had
reference_text: two Carnegie libraries, both built in 1913 – one for blacks and one for whites. A group of women had formed the Fortnightly Book and Magazine Club in the 1880s and began raising money to build a library for the city. The books they collected and shared within the club were later the basis of the library collection for Meridian. With wide support for the library, the club enlisted Israel Marks, a city leader, to approach the national philanthropist Andrew Carnegie for funding assistance. The library for blacks was built at 13th Street and 28th Avenue on land donated by St. Paul Methodist Church, and the library for whites was established in a building originally owned by members of the First Presbyterian Church of Meridian, who sold it to the city on September 25, 1911. The African American library was the only library for blacks in the state until after World War I and is the only Carnegie library ever built for African Americans in the country. The two libraries served the city until 1967, when the institutions became integrated because of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, combined their collections, and moved all materials to their current location. The former white library was renovated and converted into the Meridian Museum of Art in 1970, and the former African @-@ American library was demolished on May 28, 2008.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The island is composed of a variety of volcanic and sedimentary rock formations from the Devonian period. At that time the Scottish landmass formed part of the
reference_text: Old Red Sandstone Continent and lay some 10 @-@ 25 degrees south of the equator. The accumulations of Old Red Sandstone, laid down from 408 to 370 million years ago, were created as earlier Silurian rocks, uplifted by the formation of Pangaea, eroded and then were deposited into river deltas. The freshwater Lake Orcadie existed on the edges of the eroding mountains, stretching from Shetland to the southern Moray Firth. The structure of Papa Stour is largely made up of ashes and lavas from volcanic activity associated with this period, including bands of solidified volcanic ash and lava ( rhyolite ), but there is also a Devonian fish bed at Lamba Banks. There are numerous large boulders deposited by Pleistocene glaciation.

An island church has been discovered by archaeologists who believe it may be the remains of a Roman Catholic church dating back to the 1st century AD.

The discovery was made on the island of Fore Wick, which overlooks Kirk Sand in the bay of Fore Wick, Co Wexford. Archaeologists from Trinity College Dublin (TCD) were excavating a site when they came across what they believe is a Roman Catholic church, which was built in 1806.

Archaeologists have not been able to determine the age of the church, but they are confident that it is at least as old as the church of St Brigid's in the town of Ballyshannon, which was built in the 13th century.

Trinity College Dublin archaeologist and co-convenor of the Digitised Manuscripts and Archaeobotanies (DMA) project, Dr Michael Maguire, said: "This is one of the most exciting finds we have made in recent years. It shows that people were living on the island long before the arrival of the Normans in 1066 and that there was a church of some kind in the area at some point in the past."

Aberdeen, December 23, 1894. At 8.30 p.m. this evening an unfortuante accident occurred on the Ben Doran A178, which was in the Peacock Channel about three miles north of Papa Stour. All hands were saved by the use of lifebelts, but one man lost his life in the engine room, and two others were thrown overboard by the force of the explosion. The remaining crew of twenty-one were able to make their way to the shore, and a search was made for the missing man, but he was not found. It is believed that he was killed by the ice in the engine room or at the same time as the accident took place.

This is the second accident of this kind to befall the vessel since she was laid up in November last. In the first accident she broke in two, and in the second she struck a rock and capsized. A photo posted by New York City (@nyc) on Jun 11, 2015 at 9:56am PDT The "HIGH FIVE" sign is one of the most recognizable signs in the world, but it's not the only one to have its history traced back to the Big Apple. In fact, there are a number of similar-looking signs scattered around the United States and the world, including the one in the photo above. The signs were created by advertising firm Ogilvy & Mather in the 1920s as a way to advertise the company's high-speed trains to and from New York City. The company was so successful with the sign that it went on to create a number of similar signs for other cities, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. In all cases, the sign features a stylized image of the Empire State Building in the center, flanked by the words "Empire State High-Speed Trains" and "The World's Largest Elevated Train Station."

The fees ranged from $ 50 to a high of $ 110 @,@ 000 for rush hours. In order not to interfere with traffic flow during construction, the new interchange was designed largely as elevated flyover ramps and viaducts so they could be built high over the existing junction lanes ; once traffic was transferred to the new structures the old lanes could simply be closed off and removed. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The terrain in the Trout Creek Mountains varies from broad, flat basins and rolling ridges to high rock escarpments cut by deep canyons.
reference_text: The canyons have steep walls with loose talus slopes at the bottoms. There are meadows around springs in the mountains, although most streams in the range do not flow year @-@ round. Major streams that flow off the north slopes of the mountains include ( from west to east ) Cottonwood Creek, Trout Creek, Willow Creek, and Whitehorse Creek. These streams all flow into endorheic basins in Harney County, Oregon. Trout Creek and Whitehorse Creek are the largest of the four. The Kings River and McDermitt Creek each drain an area on the south slopes of the Trout Creek Mountains. The Kings River begins in The Granites and flows south into Nevada, where it meets the Quinn River, which evaporates in the Black Rock Desert. McDermitt Creek begins in Oregon a few miles north of The Granites and flows generally east, crossing the Oregon – Nevada border five times before disappearing into the floor of the Quinn River Valley south of McDermitt.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today. Crustal thinning and the
reference_text: Yellowstone hotspot, which was then beneath southeastern Oregon, induced eruptions from Steens and nearby vents about 17 million years ago, in the Miocene. The vents produced a series of lava flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains. Eruptions from the Steens volcano lasted for about one million years, and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred. Under the resulting basalt rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to some of the Triassic age formations of the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon. Within these metamorphic rocks are diorite and granodiorite intrusive bodies which were presumably intruded during the Cretaceous Period.

Trout Creek's elevation is about 2,000 feet higher than the state's highest peak, Mount Baldy, which is at 3,895 feet. The peak of Steens Mountain is the highest point in New Mexico and one of the most popular destinations for rock climbers in the state.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The broad McDermitt Caldera is a prominent geologic feature in the Trout Creek Mountains. The oval @-@ shaped caldera is a collapsed
reference_text: lava dome that straddles the Oregon – Nevada border on the eastern side of the range and south of the Oregon Canyon Mountains. It is about 28 miles ( 45 km ) long and 22 miles ( 35 km ) wide. The lava dome was created by volcanic eruptions in the early Miocene. A total of five large ash flows were produced along with a large rhyolite dome structure. The caldera formed when the dome collapsed about 16 million years ago. The caldera contains significant ore deposits, and mercury and uranium have been mined at eight or more sites in and around the caldera. Other areas in the caldera were mined for ores of antimony, cesium, and lithium.

McDermitt Caldera, as it appears from the top of Mt. Shasta (Photo: U.S. Geological Survey)

In addition to its size, the caldera is notable for its size in relation to its surroundings. This is because the area of the caldera is divided into two halves by a fault, which runs parallel to the San Andreas Fault. The fault has been active since the Pleistocene Epoch (about 11,000 years ago), and its history is well documented in rock strata that date back as far as 100,000 years. This means that there is a lot of material to work with when it comes to studying the history of the caldera.

A close-up view of the McMurdo Dry Valleys in the McMurdo Dry Valleys National Park and Preserve (Photo: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)

A bridge over the Susquehanna River was built in 1842, and it was the first of its kind in the United States at that time. Geography Edit

Tikal is a Maya city on the Yucatán Peninsula, about 200 km (124 mi) south of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. The city has a population of about 1.5 million people, of which more than half live in the city center and are referred to as "highlanders" because of their lifestyle, which includes hunting, fishing, and farming. There are two main roads that connect Tikal to the rest of the world: the Old City Road (also known as the Road of the Dead) and the New City Road.[1] Both roads are in good condition, but the Old City Road is more well-traveled due to its shorter distance between the cities, and the number of tourists who visit each year is much higher than the number of highlanders in the city.

Inhabitants Edit

The population of Tikal is divided into two groups: the highlanders and the lowlanders. The highlanders are a nomadic people who live in the highlands,

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Tikal was the capital of a conquest state that became one of the most powerful kingdoms of the ancient Maya. Though monumental architecture at the site dates back as
reference_text: far as the 4th century BC, Tikal reached its apogee during the Classic Period, c. 200 to 900 AD. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily, while interacting with areas throughout Mesoamerica such as the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexico. There is evidence that Tikal was conquered by Teotihuacan in the 4th century AD. Following the end of the Late Classic Period, no new major monuments were built at Tikal and there is evidence that elite palaces were burned. These events were coupled with a gradual population decline, culminating with the site ’ s abandonment by the end of the 10th century.

Tikal has been excavated in the last three decades by a team led by archaeologist David Freidel of the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB). Freidel's team has been using ground-penetrating radar (GPR) to map the city, and in a paper published in the May/June issue of Antiquity, they report that a total of 1,890 m2 of the city is covered by layers of volcanic ash that were deposited during eruptions that occurred between the ninth and twelfth centuries. This is the largest amount of volcanic ash ever recorded in a pre-Columbian city, and it indicates that the volcano was active for at least a thousand years before the fall of Tenochtitlan in 1521.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The name Tikal may be derived from ti ak 'al in the Yucatec Maya language ; it is said to be a relatively modern name meaning
reference_text: " at the waterhole ". The name was apparently applied to one of the site's ancient reservoirs by hunters and travelers in the region. It has alternatively been interpreted as meaning " the place of the voices " in the Itza Maya language. Tikal, however, is not the ancient name for the site but rather the name adopted shortly after its discovery in the 1840s. Hieroglyphic inscriptions at the ruins refer to the ancient city as Yax Mutal or Yax Mutul, meaning " First Mutal ". Tikal may have come to have been called this because Dos Pilas also came to use the same emblem glyph ; the rulers of the city presumably wanted to distinguish themselves as the first city to bear the name. The kingdom as a whole was simply called Mutul, which is the reading of the " hair bundle " emblem glyph seen in the accompanying photo. Its precise meaning remains obscure.

Caracol, or Calakmul, was an important city in Mesoamerica, located in the Yucatan Peninsula, south of the Gulf of Mexico. It was one of the most important cities in the pre-Columbian New World before the arrival of the Aztecs (A.D. 500-1521).[1]

Contents show]

Geography Edit

Caracol was a city-state on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico, about 20 miles (32 km) south of Tampico and a few miles (km) north of Puerto Vallarta. Its location made it vulnerable to raids by the Olmecs, a nomadic people who were known for pillaging and plundering the coast and coastal areas of Mesoamerica. In 711 C.E., the Olmecs attacked the city with a force of at least 10,000 warriors, and destroyed it in one night.[2]

Tikal is located in the heart of what is now known as the Pamir Mountains, a range of mountain ranges that run from the Caspian Sea in the west to the Himalayas in the east. The Pamir Mountains have been the scene of a number of wars between nomadic tribes, most notably the Kushan-Mongol war of the 3rd century BC, which resulted in the death of Khubilai Khan, the founder of the Yuan Dynasty (1271-1368).

During the 13th century, the Mongols invaded the region, but were repelled by Genghis Khan's grandson Tamerlane in 1241. After the Mongol invasions, the region fell under the control of the Mamluk sultanate of Egypt, which ruled it until 1876. In 1878, the Ottomans conquered the region and established the Transoxian Railway, which led to the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869.

The city grew to become the largest and most important city in the region, and it was at one time home to more than 10,000 people. But by the time the Spanish arrived in the 15th century, there were only a few thousand people left in the city, and it was in the hands of the Moctezuma dynasty (the rulers of the 16th century) and its vassal kings.

It developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period, with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period.

It contains the world's largest pre-Columbian Mayan city, which was built between 500 and 900 AD. The pyramid complex at Tikal consists of nine pyramids and a number of smaller structures, some of which date back to the 3rd millennium BC.

In 1821, an earthquake destroyed the temple and all the structures around it, including the pyramid. The ruins were rediscovered in the 1930s and have been excavated ever since.

Temple 33 was built in 1879-1880 by a group of French-Egyptian antiquarians led by Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne-L'Ouverture, who excavated the site from 1879 to 1881. Le Moyne-L'Ouverture's tomb was located on the north side of the pyramid, and his remains were exhumed for the construction of the pyramid. In addition to the tombs of Le Moyne-L'Ouverture and his wife, the pyramid had a chamber dedicated to the goddess Hathor, as well as an underground chamber for the mummification of the deceased.

After the death of Le Moyne-L'Ouverture, the site was taken over by the French archaeologist and anthropologist Henri Pirenne, who was responsible for the excavation of the pyramid and its burial chamber. Pirenne had a close relationship with Napoleon Bonaparte, and the two worked side by side to excavate the pyramid, which was completed in 1884. The pyramid was named in honor of the

reference_text: built into the end of the East Plaza Ballcourt and possessed four entry doorways and three stairways, the fourth ( south ) side was too close to the Central Acropolis for a stairway on that side. The building has a talud @-@ tablero platform profile, modified from the original style found at Teotihuacan. In fact, it has been suggested that the style of the building has closer affinities with El Tajin and Xochicalco than with Teotihuacan itself. The vertical tablero panels are set between sloping talud panels and are decorated with paired disc symbols. Large flower symbols are set into the sloping talud panels, related to the Venus and star symbols used at Teotihuacan. The roof of the structure was decorated with friezes although only fragments now remain, showing a monstrous face, perhaps that of a jaguar, with another head emerging from the mouth. The second head possesses a bifurcated tongue but is probably not that of a snake. The temple, and its associated ballcourt, probably date to the reign of Nuun Ujol Chaak or that of his son Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I, in the later part of the 7th century.

The building began as a pair of pyramids, each with a diameter of 1.5 km (1.2 mi; 2.2 mi). prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Mount Elbert is part of the Sawatch Range, an uplift of the Laramide Orogeny which separated from the Mosquito Range to the
reference_text: east around 28 million years ago. The tops of this range were heavily glaciated, leaving behind characteristic summit features and other such clues. For example, the base of Elbert on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited when the glaciers receded, which lie on a lateral moraine. Further up the eastern side there is a large cirque with a small tarn. There are also lakes to both the north and south, Turquoise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines, and Turquoise Lake was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam.

In 1855, John Wesley Powell was the first to describe Mount Elbert in a letter to the San Francisco Bulletin. He wrote that it was "the highest point in the United States and one of the most picturesque in the world" and that "there is no mountain of this country which compares with it in beauty and grandeur."

Powell's description was based on observations made in the summer of 1855 and the following winter. In addition to Powell's description, there are a number of mountain guides that claim to have climbed Mount Elbert, but none of these are confirmed by scientific evidence.

The most famous mountaineer to have climbed Mount Elbert is George Mallory, better known as the "Rip Van Winkle of the Sierra Nevadas." Mallory is credited with summiting Mount St. Helens in 1873, but this has been disputed by other mountaineers.

Mallory's claim to fame is that he summited Mount McKinley in 1894 without oxygen and in less than 24 hours. The record for the fastest ascent from the South Col is held by Sir Edmund Hillary

reference_text: @,@ 440 feet ( 4 @,@ 400 m ) following a re @-@ evaluation of mapped elevations, which sparked protests. The actual change was made in 1988 as a result of the North American Vertical Datum of 1988 ; it seems the original measurement resulted from the Sea Level Datum of 1929. A matter of some contention arose after the Great Depression over the heights of Elbert and its neighbor, Mount Massive, which differ in elevation by only 12 feet ( 3 @.@ 7 m ). This led to an ongoing dispute that came to a head with the Mount Massive supporters building large piles of stones on the summit to boost its height, only to have the Mount Elbert proponents demolish them. The effort was ultimately unsuccessful and Mount Elbert has remained the highest peak in Colorado. The first motorized ascent of Elbert occurred in 1949, when a Jeep was driven to the summit, apparently to judge suitability for skiing development.

MOUNTAIN BIKING FACILITIES

There are two mountain biking trails that lead to the summit of Mount Elbert. The first is a 2.5 mile loop that takes you up the side of the mountain, past the parking area and along the summit ridge. The second is a 1.5 mile out and back trail that is used for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Both trails have signs to direct you to the trailhead, but you are free to choose your own way to get there.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Although strenuous and requiring physical fitness, none of the conventional routes require specialist mountaineering skills or technical rock climbing. The main dangers of the mountain are
reference_text: those common to all high mountains, particularly altitude sickness. This can affect anyone, even those who are acclimatized. In serious cases, it can lead to high @-@ altitude pulmonary edema and cerebral edema, which can lead to difficulties with breathing, paralysis, and death. Climbers are advised to begin their ascent at or before 6 a.m. and to summit and descend before early afternoon to minimize exposure to possible afternoon thunderstorms while at high altitudes. Although the most conventional form of ascent is by hiking, Anna Elizabeth Dickinson, the orator, ascended the mountain on a mule borrowed from the U.S. government.

History [ edit ]

Early settlers in the 1800s built huts on the summit, which were used by Native Americans for hunting and shelter. The first ascent was made by John Muir in 1849.[1] In the mid-19th century, a group of mountain bikers made the first ascent of the mountain using a rope and pulley system, but the route was abandoned after one of the riders fell to his death.[2]

During World War II, the United States Air Force conducted training exercises in the area to prepare pilots for high altitudes and mountain climbing. The base camp for Operation Overlord was located at Camp Pendleton, about 20 miles (32 km) north of the summit. A total of 1,8

Harvey armour was a form of armour designed to protect ships from torpedoes by deflecting the shock waves and splintered wood and metal fragments that would cause damage to the ship and its crew. It was made of steel plates that were riveted together at the ends and had a thickness of 2 to 3 inches (5 to 8 cm). This made it difficult to penetrate, but not impenetrable. In the case of a torpedo, the armour would deflect the torpedo into the water, allowing the ship to continue its course unimpeded.

History Edit

Asahi was one of the ships that participated in the Battle of Midway in 1942, where her gunnery officer Lt. (jg) Shigemitsu Nakanishi shot down a Ki-43-II dive bomber with a P-40 Warhawk and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his actions. She returned to the United States for refit and training in San Diego, California.[1]

In the Pacific War, Asahi served as a training ship for carrier-based aircraft and aircraft carriers. On the night of December 7, 1944, the Japanese carrier I-58 attacked Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, with a force of over 1,000 aircraft. After several days of air attacks, the U.S. battleship Oklahoma (BB-37) and the aircraft carrier Hornet (CV-6) arrived to provide air cover for the I-58. On December 10, the two aircraft carriers were attacked by the I-58 and their escorts, the destroyers Taffy 3 and Hiryu, as well as the escort carrier Saratoga (CV-9). After the war [ edit ]

In the 1950s and 1960s, the aircraft carrier was decommissioned and used as a training ship for the Maritime Self-Defense Force (MSDF). It was sold to Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 1964 for scrapping, but was saved from oblivion by the efforts of a group of former shipwrights who worked to restore the ship to its former glory and make it a museum ship for the city of Nagasaki, Japan. Asahi was placed on display in the city until her restoration was completed in the mid-1980s. In the early 1990s, the Japanese government decided to sell the ship to private owners, and in 1995 it was purchased by Japan Air Self-Defense Force (JASDF) captain Shigetoshi Yamauchi and his business partner Tetsuzo Kataoka. Yamauchi had been a pilot in the air force before joining the aviation industry, and Kataoka was an executive at Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at the time of the purchase. This was the first time in American history that a state legislature had attempted to abolish the Electoral College. The bill passed the House of Representa­tives on December 2, 1936, but died in the Senate after being filibustered by a coalition of Republicans and Democrats led by Sen. On January 6, 1937, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt signed the Twenty-fifth Amendment abolishing the Electoral College into law. The following day, a joint session of Congress voted to ratify the Twentieth Amendment in a voice vote.

Fort Sullivan was the first of its kind to be built by the British and the United States during the Revolutionary War (1775-1783). In 1776, General Washington was given command of the fort and ordered to fortify it as soon as possible. The plan was to build a wall from sea to sea, and then use the water as a defense against the British invasion of the North American Colonies.

Construction of the fort began in the spring of 1777, and was completed in September that year. The walls were constructed of palmetto logs (the wood used for ship timbers), and covered with tar-soaked canvas. The fort was named after the commander in chief of the British forces in North America, Sir William Sullivan.

After the war, the fort was used as a trading post for a few years, but it was abandoned in 1816. Today, it is a National Historic Landmark and an important part of the Chesapeake Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve.

The raid took place on January 1798 at the Battle of Malabon, which was part of the French-Philippine War of 1798-1801. In the early morning hours of that day, a fleet of French warships led by Admiral Leclerc sailed from Porto Bello to the island of Mindanao in the South China Sea. Leclerc's fleet consisted of two frigates, a frigate-carrier, and several destroyers.[1]

After landing on Mindanao, Leclerc's fleet set sail for Manila, the capital of the Philippines. However, before they could do so, the French were ambushed by an unknown force and forced to retreat. As a result, they did not have enough time to complete their reconnaissance mission, and were forced to turn back to their base in the Philippines. The French lost over 1,000 men in the battle, including several admirals, a lieutenant-colonel, and several colonels.[1]

The battle was an important turning point in the war, as it resulted in the capture of Vimy Ridge, one of the most important objectives on the Western Front.

This is the most common question I get about Sonic the Hedgehog, so I'm going to answer it in one fell swoop.


Sonic has always been teal in color. The blue was a stylistic choice by Shueisha, not an official color. It was used for promotional purposes at the time, as well as to differentiate Sonic from Tails, who was in the same color scheme. In the US, however, Sonic was given a more solid blue-ish color scheme, and Tails was given a more yellow-ish color scheme. This has remained the standard ever since.


Now, let's talk about the colors that are considered "alternate" colors. There are a few, but they're not as common as you might think. The ones that come to mind are Pink, Green, and Yellow. These are the colors that have been used in the games since the first one, and they're the ones that most people associate with the character.

The gameplay originated with a tech demo by Naka, who developed an algorithm allowing a sprite to move smoothly on a curve by determining its position with a dot matrix. Naka's prototype was a platform game with a fast @-@ moving character rolling in a ball through a long, winding tube, and this concept was fleshed out with Ohshima's character designs and levels by designer Hirokazu Yasuhara. Yasuhara originally intended to work on the game for three months due to the delay of his planned move to the United States by the outbreak of the Gulf War, but was engrossed in the project for nearly a year. His designs for levels were intended to attract both hardcore and casual gamers by integrating occasional challenging set pieces into the mostly accessible level design. The game's color scheme was influenced by the work of pop artist Eizin Suzuki, and the aesthetics of Green Hill were influenced by the geography of California.

In order to achieve his goal of conquering the world, Sonic must collect Chaos Emeralds, which are scattered throughout the game world. Each Emerald has a power associated with it, and the player must use these powers to defeat enemies and reach the end of the level.

Awards and accolades [ edit ]

Super Mario All-Stars was nominated for a Golden Joystick Award in the Best Game of the Year category.[1] It took home the award for "Outstanding Achievement in Art Direction" and "Outstanding Achievement in Storytelling".[2] The game was also inducted into the Guinness World Records Gamer's Edition as the fastest game to sell 1 million copies in the United States.[3]

Reception [ edit ]

Super Mario All-Stars received mixed reviews from critics. Some praised the game for its innovative gameplay, while others were disappointed that there were no levels that took advantage of the Game Boy's screen real estate. IGN gave the game a 7.5/10, stating that "Mario's adventures have been a staple of videogames for more than 30 years, but this is the first time he's had to deal with all the challenges thrown at him in a single game."[4] GamesRadar gave the game a 7.5/10, stating that "Super Mario All-Stars is an excellent entry in the series, one that will appeal to fans

Scheduled to release in the fall of 1993, Sega of America was in the midst of a transition in its top management, with the departure of CEO Michael Eisner in the fall of that year. Eisner's successor, Scott Rohde, took over the company in February 1994, and the first game in the Sonic the Hedgehog series was delayed several times before finally coming out in November of that year.

In addition to the release of Sonic the Hedgehog 2, Sega also released two games based on the video game of the same name, one of which was developed by Hudson Soft (the company responsible for The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time and Donkey Kong Country). Both games sold well, and the company's sales were up over 50 percent year-over-year at the end of 1994.

However, it was not to last. Rohde was replaced by Hiroshi Yamauchi, a former president of Nintendo and one of the most powerful men in the world. Yamauchi had no love for Sega, and was quick to make his displeasure known in an interview with Game Informer,

These two tours were created in May 1986 through a joint effort between MDOT and its counterparts in Wisconsin, Minnesota and Ontario. The section of US 2 between Iron River and Crystal Falls has been named the Iron County Heritage Trail. This Pure Michigan Byway was designated to honor the " rich history of two industries that built a state and nation : mining and logging. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Before 1983, US 2 used a different routing through Manistique and crossed the Manistique River on what is nicknamed the " Siphon Bridge "
reference_text: Built as a part of a raceway flume on the river, the water level is actually higher than the road surface. This produces a siphon effect, giving the bridge its nickname. The Manistique Pulp and Paper Company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the Manistique River to supply their mill. This dam would require a large section of the city to be flooded, and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge construction. Instead of expensive dikes, a concrete tank was built lengthwise in the river bed ; the sides of this tank provided man @-@ made banks higher than the natural banks. The Michigan Works Progress Administration described the bridge as having " concrete bulkheads, formed by the side spans of the bridge, [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed. " The Manistique Tourism Council stated : " At one time, the bridge itself was partially supported by the water that was atmospherically forced under it, " and that the bridge has been featured in Ripley's Believe It or Not!. The eight @-@ span structure is 294 feet ( 90 m ) long.

History in the United States Edit

Carey began the tour in New York City on September 22, 2000 at Madison Square Garden with a sold out show that was attended by over 20,000 people. The tour continued to the West Coast, where it was held at Los Angeles' Staples Center on October 5, 2000. The concert was held to promote the release of Carey's album, Butterfly.[1]

After the tour ended, Carey returned to her home in Malibu, California to work on her next album and tour the country in support of it. In the summer of 2001, Carey was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Spice Girls for her work with the group from the 1980s and 1990s. The following year, she performed at the Grammys, becoming the first artist to do so in 20 years (others who were inducted in that year were Michael Jackson, Stevie Nicks, Elton John, Bob Seger, Neil Sedgwick, John Mellencamp, The Rolling Stones, Paul Anastasio, Bruce Springthorpe, and the Beach Boys).

The longhouse and windmill at Thelnetham, near Basingstoke, are one of the oldest buildings in the village, dating from the reign of Queen Victoria (1837-1901). They were built by millwright George Bloomfield for William Button in 1819 to replace an old post mill which had been in use for more than 200 years.

The millwright's name is inscribed on the side of the building, along with the date of the building, 1819. This was the year Button was appointed to the post of Master of Balliol College, Oxford, and his appointment was a sign of the esteem in which he was held by the college.

In the summer of 1819, a storm blew down the chimney of the old mill, and the building was in danger of collapse. Button had to improvise a way of keeping the mill running, and this led to the design of the longhouse, which was completed in two months. He used materials from the old mill, including timbers from the roof, and built the structure on stilts to save money.

The building has been a centre of activity ever since, and is open to the public on

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The mill was worked by Stephen Peverett, Richard's son. He inherited the mill on the death of his father in 1875 and leased it to
reference_text: Henry Bryant in 1879. In 1884, the mill was sold by auction, and Henry Bryant purchased the freehold. Bryant rebuilt the floors of the mill. From 1892, a portable steam engine was used as auxiliary power, driving an extra pair of millstones on the ground floor. This was replaced in 1914 by a Hornsby oil engine. Bryant ran the mill until 1920 when he sold it to Alphonso Vincent, a retired millwright from Garboldisham, Norfolk. The Hornsby engine was sold in the early 1920s. The mill was tailwinded c1920, and as a result one pair of sails was removed. Vincent carried out some repairs to the mill and ran it until he retired in 1924. One of the remaining two sails was wrecked in 1926 when the mill was again tailwinded.

A family of squatters in the middle of a derelict housing estate have become something of a celebrity, thanks to photographs taken by a BBC camera crew.

Alphonso Vincent, the son of a London police constable, died in 1932 after falling from a third-floor window of his family home in Battersea, south London. The house was in disrepair and had no heating, so he was unable to call for help.

In the decades that followed, it became the scene of a series of squalor-related deaths, including that of a baby, which was found in a cot with its umbilical cord still attached. It was taken to a mortuary, where it was pronounced dead by a doctor on the spot.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: BBC/Hulton Archive/Getty Images

Vincent's death was one of the first in a series of squatters' deaths that would continue for decades, and the story of their lives has been chronicled in a documentary, Inside the Squatters' Cottage, which aired on BBC2 last night.

It is a story of poverty, neglect and the struggle to stay alive in a city that has changed beyond recognition in the

The church was built in the 12th century and has survived for at least 500 years. It is one of the oldest churches in the county, dating from the reign of Henry II (1154-1199) and the Norman Conquest of 1066. In the early 16th century a chapel was added to the north side of the nave, with a bell tower on the south side. This was the first time the tower was used as a bell tower and it remained in use until the 18th century. The bell tower was destroyed by fire in 1837 and rebuilt in its present form by the Rev. W.A. Horsley (1820-1882), who was a parish priest at Newbury, in his spare time. In 1848 the church was granted a grant of £ 1,000 to repair the damage and build a new bell tower. The work was carried out by a team of craftsmen led by the Rev. J.H.W.Buckle and took two years to complete.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> For most of the last century military service has been one of the single greatest shared experiences of white Australian males, and although this is now changing due to the
reference_text: professionalisation of the military and the absence of major wars during the second half of the 20th century, it continues to influence Australian society to this day. War and military service have been defining influences in Australian history, while a major part of the national identity has been built on an idealised conception of the Australian experience of war and of soldiering, known as the Anzac spirit. These ideals include notions of endurance, courage, ingenuity, humour, larrikinism, egalitarianism and mateship ; traits which, according to popular thought, defined the behaviour of Australian soldiers fighting at Gallipoli during the First World War. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the first international events that saw Australians taking part as Australians and has been seen as a key event in forging a sense of national identity.

This is the first time in the census since the 1960s that the gender breakdown of the military has been equal to that of the non-military population.

reference_text: warfare. Indeed, Australian defence policy was closely linked to Britain until the Japanese crisis of 1942, while since then an alliance with the United States has underwritten its security. Arguably, this pattern of bandwagoning — both for cultural reasons such as shared values and beliefs, as well as for more pragmatic security concerns — has ensured that Australian strategic policy has often been defined by relations with its allies. Regardless, a tendency towards strategic complacency has also been evident, with Australians often reluctant to think about defence issues or to allocate resources until a crisis arises ; a trait which has historically resulted in unpreparedness for major military challenges.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> From 1870 until 1901, each of the six colonial governments was responsible for their own defence. The colonies had gained responsible government between 1855 and 1890, and
reference_text: while the Colonial Office in London retained control of some affairs, the Governor of the each colony was required to raise their own colonial militia. To do this, they were granted the authority from the British crown to raise military and naval forces. Initially these were militias in support of British regulars, but when military support for the colonies ended in 1870, the colonies assumed their own defence responsibilities. The colonial military forces included unpaid volunteer militia, paid citizen soldiers, and a small permanent component. They were mainly infantry, cavalry and mounted infantry, and were neither housed in barracks nor subject to full military discipline. Even after significant reforms in the 1870s — including the expansion of the permanent forces to include engineer and artillery units — they remained too small and unbalanced to be considered armies in the modern sense. By 1885, the forces numbered 21 @,@ 000 men. Although they could not be compelled to serve overseas many volunteers subsequently did see action in a number conflicts of the British Empire during the 19th century, with the colonies raising contingents to serve in Sudan, South Africa and China.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite a reputation of colonial inferiority, many of the locally raised units were highly organised, disciplined, professional, and well trained. During this period, defences
reference_text: in Australia mainly revolved around static defence by combined infantry and artillery, based on garrisoned coastal forts. However, by the 1890s, improved railway communications between the mainland eastern colonies led Major General James Edwards — who had recently completed a survey of colonial military forces — to the belief that the colonies could be defended by the rapid mobilisation of brigades of infantry. As a consequence he called for a restructure of defences, and defensive agreements to be made between the colonies. Edwards argued for the colonial forces to be federated and for professional units — obliged to serve anywhere in the South Pacific — to replace the volunteer forces. These views found support in the influential New South Wales Commandant, Major General Edward Hutton, however suspicions held by the smaller colonies towards New South Wales and Victoria stifled the proposal. These reforms remaining unresolved however, and defence issues were generally given little attention in the debate on the political federation of the colonies.

This was the birth of the Australian Commonwealth Military Forces (ACMF).

Australia's military history is dominated by World War I, the Boer War of 1899-1902 and the Second World War. However, there was a time when Australia was the most militarily powerful country in the world. During the 19th and early 20th centuries, Australia fought two wars against Great Britain and one against the United States of America.

The first war was fought between 1879 and 1883 in the War of 1812. It was a war of national liberation and resulted in the end of British rule in New South Wales and the establishment of the Australian Colony of New South Wales. The British were forced to cede the colony to the newly formed Australian Commonwealth of Australasia in return for peace and a guarantee of the safety of the shipping lanes in the Sydney Harbour.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Prior to federation each self @-@ governing colony had operated its own naval force. These navies were small and lacked blue water capabilities, forcing the separate
reference_text: colonies to subsidise the cost of a British naval squadron in their waters for decades. The colonies maintained control over their respective navies until 1 March 1901, when the Commonwealth Naval Force was created. This new force also lacked blue water capable ships, and ultimately did not lead to a change in Australian naval policy. In 1907 Prime Minister Alfred Deakin and Creswell, while attending the Imperial Conference in London, sought the British Government's agreement to end the subsidy system and develop an Australian navy. The Admiralty rejected and resented the challenge, but suggested diplomatically that a small fleet of destroyers and submarines would be sufficient. Deakin was unimpressed, and in 1908 invited the American Great White Fleet to visit Australia. This visit fired public enthusiasm for a modern navy and in part led to the order of two 700 @-@ ton River @-@ class destroyers. The surge in German naval construction prompted the Admiralty to change their position however and the Royal Australian Navy was subsequently formed in 1911, absorbing the Commonwealth Naval Force. On 4 October 1913, the new fleet steamed through Sydney Heads, consisting of the battlecruiser HMAS Australia, three light cruisers, and three destroyers, while several other ships were still under construction. And as a consequence the navy entered the First World War as a formidable force.

In this article we examine the history of the war and what it tells us about Australia's relationship with the United Empire Loyalists (UEL), a group of British-trained and -supplied officers who fought in the Boer War against the Afrikaner Nationalist (ANC) South African military.

The war began in 1899 and lasted until 1902, when the British withdrew their support for the UEL and agreed to a cease-fire. This was followed by the Anglo-Boer War (1902–1903), in which the British and Boer armies fought each other for control of Transvaal, the country's largest province.

Synopsis of the Roast Edit (0:00 - 1:10) Edit

Comedian Marc Wilmore takes on a panel of comedians to see who is funniest on the show. The panel consists of the following: Chris Rock, Dave Chappelle, Hannibal Buress, Aziz Ansari, Jim Gaffigan, Amy Poehls, Patton Oswalt, Bill Hedden, Jon Glastro, Adam Carriker, Michael Che, Kevin Nealon, Nick Kocherkasky, and Rob Lowe. Each of the comedians has a 10-minute monologue that goes over their life and what they do for a living. They are asked to make fun of each other and the rest of the panel for 10 minutes in the style of a stand-up comedy show. After the jokes are made, the audience votes on who is funniest by raising their hands in the air. This results in a tie, which is broken by the audience member who gets the most votes. In the end, Rob Lowe comes out on top by a vote of 3-2.[1]

At Moe's Tavern, Homer is playing chess with Milhouse, and they have a game of checkers. Milhouse wins the game, but Homer gets the upper hand by using Homer's head as a checkerboard to checkmate the King of the Chessboard. The King, in a fit of rage, sends Homer to the bottom of the board, where he is forced to eat a hot dog and drink a cup of hot coffee in order to regain his head. After a few minutes, Homer regains his head and returns to the top of the board, only to have his victory snatched from him once again by the King, who has Homer eaten again and is about to eat him as well. However, before he can do so, he is knocked out by a lightning bolt that strikes the King's castle, causing it to collapse on top of him.[1]

Synopsis Edit

A group of scientists from the U.S. and the Soviet Bloc are on a mission to find a way to exit the solar system without destroying the Earth. But their mission is complicated by the presence of a rogue planet in the Kuiper Belt, which is about to collide with the Earth at a momentous moment in human history. As the Earth begins to break apart, an escape pod is launched from the International Space Station (ISS) and lands on the planet, bringing with it scientists, military personnel, and the world's most famous rock star, Neil Armstrong. Neil and his crew have one week to figure out how to survive the planet's gravity, hostile environment, and other dangers before the planet collides with the Earth and all is lost. The Boat Race began in 1872 as a way to raise money for the Royal Navy and has grown to become one of the world's most prestigious rowing regattas.

History [ edit ]

Origins [ edit ]

Oxford University was founded in 1066 by Robert Fitzwilliam, a member of the House of Plantagenet who was given the title "Baron of Oxford" for his services to the university. The university became a royal college in the 11th century and was the first to admit women to the degree of Master of Arts (M.A.) in 1210. It was not until the 19th century that women were allowed to study at Oxford, and in that year a student by the name of Mary Wollstonecraft wrote The Vindication of the Rights of Woman, which sparked a debate on the role of women in society.[1] This led to the founding of the Women's Studies Society (WSS) in 1848, which would go on to play a major role in

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The post quartermaster, Captain Thomas Swords, was in charge of building Fort Scott's structures, and had to deal with the problems of construction on the
reference_text: Kansas prairie, which had few trees. He had only two bricklayers and three carpenters to rely on, as there were few civilians and most of the soldiers had other duties to perform. Freak accidents destroyed much of the wood intended for the fort's construction. Fort Cumberland, as it was known, was the largest and most important fort in the United States at the time of its construction. The fort had a population of more than 2,000, and served as a base for the Union Army during the Civil War. In addition to its military functions, Fort Cumberland played a role in the development of Tennessee's tourism industry, as well as being an important stop on the Underground Railroad.

Today, you can visit the fort and learn more about the history of the site by taking a self-guided tour. There are a number of interpretive panels that provide information about the fort and its construction, as well as an exhibit that tells the story of the Underground Railroad. The tour is free of charge, but reservations are required. For more information, call 865-639-4100.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Two years after the army abandoned the fort, the buildings were sold by auction to civilians, with two being converted to hotels. In 1854 the Kansas @
reference_text: -@ Nebraska Act repealed the Missouri Compromise of 1820, which had kept slavery out of Kansas. Missourians in favor of slavery soon moved to Kansas to try to sway the vote of whether or not Kansas would permit slavery. Settlers from New England arrived equally determined to keep it out. Each of the two competing factions of the Bleeding Kansas conflict claimed one of the hotels at Fort Scott : Free @-@ Soil at the Fort Scott Hotel and Pro @-@ Slavery at the Western Hotel. Most of the residents in Fort Scott supported slavery, but those outside the town tended to the free @-@ soil side. During this time, there were local incidents of murder and attempted arson, typical elements of the guerrilla conflicts that were prevalent in the fighting.

Fort Leavenworth became a State of Kansas, and on April 1, 1855 it was incorporated as the city of Leavenworth.

After the Civil War, the fort was used as a prison for Confederate deserters, who were sent to Leavenworth for trial by court-martial. It was also used to house the prisoners of the Battle of Antietam in 1862 and the siege of Vicksburg in 1864. During the Spanish-American War in 1898, Spanish troops under General Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna took up residence at the fort, which was renamed El Príncipe de la Reina (Spanish Fort of the Queen) in honor of the queen of Spain.

In the 1920s and 1930s, the city began to lose population, and a fire destroyed much of the city's infrastructure. In the early 1940s, construction began on an airfield for the Army Air Corps, which would become the largest in the world at the time. The first flight took place on July 7, 1944, and by the end of the year there were 2,000 planes on the airfield. However, the war ended before it could be completed, and the Army Air Corps ceased operations in 1946.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The main event was a King of the Mountain match for the TNA World Heavyweight Championship with Kevin Nash as Special Guest Ringside Enforcer between then @
reference_text: -@ champion Samoa Joe and the challengers Booker T, Christian Cage, Rhino, and Robert Roode. In a King of the Mountain match, the objective is to climb a ladder and hang the championship belt on a hook above the ring. In order to do so, a wrestler must first qualify by either pinning or making another wrestler submit in the match. A wrestler who is pinned or made to submit is this placed in a penalty box for two minutes. The match is fought under no disqualification rules. Booker T was the first to qualify by pinning Rhino after slamming him back @-@ first into the mat with his signature Book End maneuver. Rhino was this placed in the penalty box. Roode was the next to qualify after bashing a ladder Cage held with a chair into him and following with a pin. Immediately afterwards, Rhino pinned Roode with a roll @-@ up pin to qualify. Later, Joe held Booker T in his signature Coquina Clutch submission hold when Cage ascended a padded turnbuckle and jumped off onto Booker T and Joe. He followed by pinning Booker T to qualify and send Booker T to the penalty box. When Booker T was released from the box, he attacked Nash with the title belt and then attempted to hang it. Nash stopped him and then dropped Booker T back @-@ first against the mat with his signature Jackknife Powerbomb maneuver. Joe was the last to qualify by pinning Roode after slamming him back and neck @-@ first into the mat with his signature Muscle Buster maneuver. Joe then hung the title belt at 19 minutes and 49 seconds to win the competition.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Home Made Mince Pie is a 1910 American silent short comedy produced by the Thanhouser Company. The film is a comedy of circumstances, in which
reference_text: the Gale family is going to host a dinner. The focus of the humor is in a mince pie that brandy is added to in an attempt to make it more appreciable, but three people each add brandy to the pie. Everyone becomes tipsy upon eating the pie, including the family cat, and the film concludes. No cast or staff credits for this film are known. The film was released on September 27, 1910, to mixed reviews in trade publications. Reviewers mentioned that the film was too long and it was unbelievable that one pie split eight ways would be able to impact everyone. The film is presumed lost.

Plot [ edit ]

An old man and his daughter have a wedding to attend. The old man, Mr. Thouser, wants to spend the money on a horse, but his daughter, Mary, refuses to marry him until he has the money for the horse. So, Mr. Thouser goes to the grocery store and buys a can of cornmeal, which he puts in the pie dish to keep it from spoiling. After a few minutes, the pie is done and ready to eat. Mary asks her father what he did to make the pie, and he replies that he put cornmeal in it. When he tries to take a bite of the pie, he finds it hard and chews for a while before giving up the pie and returning to the store. The store is filled with people who have heard about the pie, and one of them comes in and buys it for $1.00.

At the wedding, the newlyweds sit in the parlor and eat their pie. After the meal, Mary tells her father that she does not feel well and goes to bed. Later that night

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Though the film is presumed lost, a synopsis survives in The Moving Picture World from September 24, 1910. It states : " Life in a country town is
reference_text: often tedious and tiresome, and were it not for the little dinners and teas the townsfolk are constantly given, existence in some localities would be a very dreary thing indeed. So the time honored get @-@ togethers of the small town are an established feature to the social calendar ; they are just as much a matter of necessity and as such have come to stay. The Gales thought well of this established feature. They made it a joyous occasion for themselves as well as their guests. They were hardly an overly wealthy family, and their table was never notable for an oversupply of the good things of life, but whenever they gave a dinner they cast all thoughts of economy to the country winds and worked to the one end that their guests have a pleasant time. "

The Courier is a non-player character in Fallout: New Vegas.

Contents show]

Background Edit

The Courier is an American wasteland wanderer who travels the Mojave Wasteland in search of his or her fortune.[1] They have no family, and live off the kindness of strangers, scavenging and bartering their way through the wastelands. Their goal is to make enough money to pay for their travels and get a place to call home once they are out of the desert for good and back on the west coast of the United States of America.

Realising that the album sessions were approaching the end and that the band were short on exceptional live songs, The Edge wanted to " conjure up the ultimate U2 live @-@ song ", so he imagined what he would like to hear at a future U2 show if he were a fan. After finishing the rough mix, he felt he had come up with " the most amazing guitar part and song of [ his ] life ". In an interview with Rolling Stone, Edge explained, "The idea was that there was an alien in the desert, and he had come to Earth to find a place to live and that was his home for the time being. The aliens were very, very different from us in every way, shape and form. They lived in a world without money, where everything was given to them for free. They ate grass and drank water from the desert, and had no concept of money or money's role in their lives. So we wanted to write a song about that, and that's what 'Where the Streets Have No Name' was about."

Hamlyn, an independent filmmaker based in Los Angeles, has a history of working with law enforcement and the police brutality that goes with it. In 2014, he made a documentary about the death of Eric Garner, a Staten Island man who died after being placed in a chokehold by New York Police Officer Daniel Pantaleo. The film was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature, but lost to Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11.

This is not the first time Hamlyn has faced police intimidation while filming police in the United States. Last year, police threatened to arrest him for filming a traffic stop in North Carolina, which is a violation of state law. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> " Silver and Gold " was written in support of the Artists United Against Apartheid project, which protested the South African apartheid. In 1985, Bono participated
reference_text: in Steven Van Zandt's anti @-@ apartheid Sun City project and spent time with Keith Richards and Mick Jagger of The Rolling Stones. When Richards and Jagger played blues, Bono was embarrassed by his lack of familiarity with the genre, as most of U2's musical knowledge began with punk rock in their youth in the mid @-@ 1970s. The song was described by Musician as " tough and raw, with Bono in husky and confident voice, underpinned by a sinuous bass line, and with The Edge demonstrating his newfound prowess in blues @-@ based guitar. Biography and Filmography Edit

Sutherland was born in Los Angeles, California and grew up in New York City. His parents divorced when he was young, and he spent a lot of time with his mother and stepfather, a man named Jack Pellitt (who is portrayed by Sutherland in the film). Sutherland has stated that the relationship was "tense" and a source of conflict in his childhood.[1]

At the age of 12, Sutherland began acting in school plays, and by the mid-1980s he was a well-known child actor in New York City. In the early 1990s, Sutherland made his film debut in the short film I'm Gonna Get You, which was directed by John Landis (The Blues Brothers, Animal Crackers), and starred the future star of Pulp Fiction, Danny Trejo. The film received mixed reviews from critics, but was a box office success for its distributor, Warner Bros. Sutherland went on to work with Landis on several films, including A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984), The Running Man (1988), Night of the Living Dead (1968), and Friday the

Plot and Characters Edit

In the film, we follow the story of an office worker named Jack as he works his way through a series of jobs, each of which ends with him losing his job and becoming a "loser" to his co-workers. After being fired from his last job, Jack decides to take a job as a janitor at a high school, but his boss has other plans for him. The two begin a battle of wits, with Jack trying to outmaneuver his boss and get the job he wants, while his boss uses his power to keep Jack from achieving his dream.

During this time, she met her husband and co-star, Richard Armitage, who was an oncologist and the father of her child. The couple got married in a civil ceremony on the steps of Buckingham Palace, and were the first same-sex couple to be married in the UK.

After a year of maternity leave, Ayola returned to work at St Bartholomew's, this time as a consultant in obstetrics and gynaecology (OG&G, the area of medicine dealing with pregnancy and childbirth). Luoyang had a population of more than 100,000 at the time of the Warring States period (475 B.C. to 221 B.C.), and its prosperity was based on trade with Central Asia and the Silk Road. It was one of the most important cities in the Tang dynasty, and the capital of the province of Luoyang, which extended from the Yangtze River to the Yellow River.

The city was surrounded by walls, and the king's palace was on the top of a hill, which served as a watchtower to watch for intruders. In order to protect the city, there were a number of fortresses in the surrounding area, including the city of Huaiyuan, which was built around the Great Wall of Luoyang.

During the Spring and Autumn Period (A.D. 518–476), the Han dynasty came to power in China, and the Tang dynasty was overthrown by the Manchus. After the fall of the Tang dynasty, Luoyang continued to function as a trading center and military base, but it was no longer an important city.

He mastered all the forms of Chinese poetry : Chou says that in every form he " either made outstanding advances or contributed outstanding examples ". Furthermore, his poems use a wide range of registers, from the direct and colloquial to the allusive and self @-@ consciously literary. This variety is manifested even within individual works : Owen identifies the, " rapid stylistic and thematic shifts " in poems which enable the poet to represent different facets of a situation, while Chou uses the term " juxtaposition " as the major analytical tool in her work. Du Fu is noted for having written more on poetics and painting than any other writer of his time. He wrote eighteen poems on painting alone, more than any other Tang poet. In the first century B.C., the historian Sima Qian wrote that there were two types of literature in China: "literature of the old and literature of the new." This dichotomy persists to this day, with the former being regarded as the product of a bygone era, and the latter as the product of a time of rapid change.

The Chinese have been writing for at least 2,000 years, but it was not until the Song dynasty (960–1279) that they began to make a name for themselves as a literary culture. During this period, which lasted from 907 to 1127, the Chinese developed a highly literate writing system based on ideograms, which is the system of pictograms used to represent sound in Chinese writing. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> It was in the 11th century, during the Northern Song era that Du Fu's reputation reached its peak. In this period a comprehensive re @-
reference_text: @ evaluation of earlier poets took place, in which Wang Wei, Li Bai and Du Fu came to be regarded as representing respectively the Buddhist, Daoist and Confucian strands of Chinese culture. At the same time, the development of Neo @-@ Confucianism ensured that Du Fu, as its poetic exemplar, occupied the paramount position. Su Shi famously expressed this reasoning when he wrote that Du Fu was " preeminent... because... through all his vicissitudes, he never for the space of a meal forgot his sovereign ". His influence was helped by his ability to reconcile apparent opposites : political conservatives were attracted by his loyalty to the established order, while political radicals embraced his concern for the poor. Literary conservatives could look to his technical mastery, while literary radicals were inspired by his innovations. Since the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Du Fu's loyalty to the state and concern for the poor have been interpreted as embryonic nationalism and socialism, and he has been praised for his use of simple, " people's language ".

He served as generalissimo of the Han dynasty from 1135 to 1189, and during this time he had the opportunity to study the military strategies of the Mongols, Huns, Genghis Khan, and other conquerors of the time.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Until the 13th century, the Japanese preferred Bai Juyi above all poets and there were few references to Du Fu, although his influence can be seen

The first notable Japanese appreciator of Du Fu's poetry was Kokan Shiren ( 1278 – 1346 ), a Rinzai Zen patriarch and one of the most prominent authors of the literature of the Five Mountains ; he highly praised Du Fu and made a commentary on some poems of Du Fu from the perspective of a Zen priest in Vol. 11 of Saihokushū. His student Chūgan Engetsu composed many kanshi which were clearly stated " influenced by Du Fu " in their prefaces. Chūgan's student Gidō Shūshin had close connection with the Court and Ashikaga Shogunate and propagated Du Fu's poetry in the mundane world ; one day Nijō Yoshimoto, the Kampaku regent of the Court and the highest authority of renga poetry, asked Gidō, " Should I learn the poetry of Du Fu and Li Bai? " Gidō dared to reply, " Yes if you do have enough capability. No if do not. " Since then, there had been many seminars on Du Fu's poetry both in Zen temples and in the aristocratic society, and as a result his poetry was often cited in Japanese literature in the Muromachi period, e.g., Taiheiki, a historical epic in the late 14th century, and some noh plays such as Hyakuman, Bashō, and Shunkan.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> A variety of styles have been used in efforts to translate Du Fu's work into English. As Burton Watson remarks in The Selected Poems of Du Fu
reference_text: , " There are many different ways to approach the problems involved in translating Du Fu, which is why we need as many different translations as possible " ( p. xxii ). The translators have had to contend with bringing out the formal constraints of the original without sounding laboured to a Western ear ( particularly when translating regulated verse, or lǜshi ), and accommodating the complex allusions contained particularly in the later works ( Hawkes writes that " his poems do not as a rule come through very well in translation " — p. ix ). One extreme on each issue is represented by Kenneth Rexroth's One Hundred Poems From the Chinese. His are free translations, which seek to conceal the parallelisms through enjambement and expansion and contraction of the content ; his responses to the allusions are firstly to omit most of these poems from his selection, and secondly to " translate out " the references in those works which he does select.

(p. 4), "It is hard to say which is the most successful, but all the translators have their share of admirers" (Watson, p. xi). This article attempts to identify the style that best fits the poems and, in the process, provides a guide to translation practice.

The Chinese term for translation is 名語 (jiǎngpì), which means "to put into another language" or "to make a translation from another language into one's own language." In other words, a translator is an interpreter of a work in another language, using the language of the original as a starting point and working from there. This is a relatively new concept in the world of literature, and one that has received little attention in English-language translations of Chinese literature. However, it is an important part of the translation process, especially when dealing with poetry, which is written in a language that is not the author's native tongue.

[4] The Yamato-class was designed as a multi-purpose warship, capable of carrying a wide variety of armaments and serving as a base for other ships of the class. It was the first class of battleships to be equipped with a quadruple torpedo tube, allowing it to fire torpedoes from four directions at once. This was an improvement over the single-tube design of the Type 0 and Type 1 cruisers and destroyers, which had limited range and were vulnerable to being torpedoed while in port. The design also had the advantage of being able to launch aircraft without having to change the ship's flight deck and thus reducing the time it took to get an aircraft off the deck to the point where it could be launched.

Kampon is a brand name for liquid hydrocarbons (LPG, propane, butane, etc.) used in cooking and as lubricants. It is the most common fuel in the world, with a market share of more than 90% in some countries. The name comes from the German word "Kampf", which means "boiler room" in German. Kampon can be made from a wide variety of hydrocrates, but most are petroleum-based and have a boiling point of about 300-350°C (570-700°F). They are highly flammable, and their vapors are highly corrosive to metal surfaces, so care must be taken to avoid contact with them when working with oxidizing or caustic materials.


In addition to their use as fuel, Kampon is a component of many industrial processes, including plastics, ceramics, paper-making, textiles, and other manufacturing processes. It is also used to make plastics that are strong, light, and easy to handle. In this photo, a piece of plastic is being cut by a laser cutter

Design and construction Edit

The Japanese Navy had a long history of designing and building aircraft carriers, but none were as large in size as the IJN's Type 0 carrier. In addition to being one of the largest warships in the world, the ship was built in a manner that would allow it to carry a wide variety of aircraft, such as long-range anti-aircraft guns, dive bombers, and fighter escorts. This was achieved by using a design known as "torsion keel" construction, which was an innovative method of construction in which the hull was held together by torsion bars, rather than rivets.[1] The design was

These experiments led to the design of the "Achille Lauro" (Lucky Eagle), a large propeller-driven rudder that was mounted on the stern of the ship. The Achille Lauro had its roots in the work of Ferdinand von Richthofen, who was a pioneer in aerodynautical engineering and the inventor of the airship. Richthofen believed that the ship would be able to travel at speeds in excess of 200 miles per hour (320 km/h or 186.5 kph), and this was enough to make him an important figure in the development of airships.

Battle of Leyte Gulf Edit

Main article: Battle of Leyte Gulf

The fleet arrived at Midway Island on the morning of December 7, 1942, where they rendezvoused with Task Force 58, led by Vice Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto. Yamamoto's task force consisted of the newly-commissioned battlescruiser Hiryū Maru, the light cruiser Asashio, and the destroyers Akitsushima Shokaku, Kumano Maru, and Naganami Maru. As a precautionary measure, the Japanese Navy had placed a total of three aircraft carriers in the battle group to provide air cover for the fleet. After exchanging gunfire with U.S. forces, the battle was over in less than two hours.[1]

In the aftermath of the battle, the Japanese surrendered unconditionally to the United States of America on December 10, 1942. On that day, Hyūga was decommissioned and placed in reserve for use as a target for anti-aircraft fire
