History Edit

On October 23, 2013, Typhoon Krosa formed in the western Pacific Ocean, about 1,000 miles (1,600 km) east of the Lesser Sunda Islands and moving west at a speed of 25 mph (40 km/h). By the morning of October 24, it had weakened to a category 1 storm with wind speeds of up to 130 mph (210 km/h).[1]

At 11:00 UTC (13:00 local time) on October 24, 2013, a storm surge of 3.5 to 5 m (10 to 15 ft) was reported at Tacloban, Leyte, and other areas of the Philippines. This surge was followed by heavy rain, flooding, landslides, and mudslides that led to the deaths of more than 1,000 people, according

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> On October 27, an area of convection with a broad circulation persisted southeast of Guam, and slowly consolidated due to moderate wind shear and westerly
reference_text: outflow. That day, the Japan Meteorological Agency ( JMA ) classified the system as a tropical depression about 380 km ( 235 mi ) to the southeast of Hagåtña, Guam. At 2100 UTC on October 28, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration ( PAGASA ) began issuing advisories on the depression, giving it the local name Vinta. The next day, the JMA upgraded the depression to Tropical Storm Krosa ( 1329 ), and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center ( JTWC ) also classified it as Tropical Depression 29W. By that time, the storm was moving steadily westward due to the subtropical ridge to the north. With the warm waters of the Philippine Sea, lessening wind shear, and improving outflow, Krosa gradually strengthened, and the JTWC also upgraded Krosa to tropical storm status on October 30 after an eye feature developed.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Commission is currently responsible for the continued commemoration of 1 @.@ 7 million deceased Commonwealth military service members in 153 countries. Since its inception, the
reference_text: Commission has constructed approximately 2 @,@ 500 war cemeteries and numerous memorials. In addition to commemorating Commonwealth military service members, the Commission maintains, under arrangement with applicable governments, over 40 @,@ 000 non @-@ Commonwealth war graves and over 25 @,@ 000 non @-@ war military and civilian graves. The Commission operates through the continued financial support of the member states : United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, India and South Africa. Commissions has worked to promote respect for human rights and the rule of law by the Commonwealth and its member states, as well as by Commonwealth-allied countries.

This website provides information on the Commission's work, including a list of Commonwealth countries that have signed the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and its Optional Protocol to the CRC, which provides a mechanism for States to report on child protection and the protection of children from sexual abuse and exploitation. The Commission also has an information page on the implementation of the CRC in the United Kingdom.

In addition, the Commission is the Commonwealth Secretariat for the International Criminal Court (ICC), which prosecutes individuals who commit crimes against humanity and war crimes in the territory of the former Yugoslavia, including the former Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro). prefix_text: <|endoftext|> As reports of the grave registration work became public, the Commission began to receive letters of enquiry and requests for photographs of graves from relatives of deceased soldiers.

The directorate's work was also extended beyond the Western Front and into other theatres of war, with units deployed in Greece, Egypt and Mesopotamia.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The scale, and associated high number of casualties, of the war produced an entirely new attitude towards the commemoration of war dead. Previous to World War I
reference_text: , individual commemoration of war dead was often on an ad hoc basis and was almost exclusively limited to commissioned officers. A committee under Frederic Kenyon, Director of the British Museum, presented a report to the Commission in November 1918 detailing how it envisioned the development of the cemeteries. Two key elements of this report were that bodies should not be repatriated and that uniform memorials should be used to avoid class distinctions. Beyond the logistical nightmare of returning home so many corpses, it was felt that repatriation would conflict with the feeling of brotherhood that had developed between serving ranks.

By that time, there were about 1,500 corpses in the camp, of which 1,000 were to be cremated every day. This was a considerable increase from the number of corpses that had been brought to the camp in the first months of the war and the camp had no capacity to deal with this increase. It was decided to increase the capacity of the camp by building a new crematorium and crematorium chimney.

On 22 July 1941, the first batch of corpses arrived at the camp and were put on conveyor belts to take them to the crematorium. The corpses were placed in the crematorium by means of a system of lorries, which were equipped with gas chambers. The gas chambers were built in the basement of the crematorium building, which was located next to the morgue. The morgue was used for disposing of the bodies of the dead who had died of typhus, dysentery (pneumonia) or other diseases. This morgue was a large room with a capacity of 50-60 corpses at a time. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Most headstones are inscribed with a cross, except for those deceased known to be atheist or non @-@ Christian. In the case of burials of
reference_text: Victoria Cross or George Cross recipients, the regimental badge is supplemented by the Victoria Cross or George Cross emblem. Sometimes a soldier employed a pseudonym because they were too young to serve or were sought by law enforcement ; in such cases their primary name is shown along with the notation " served as ". Many headstones are for unidentified casualties ; they consequently bear only what could be discovered from the body. The epitaph, developed by Rudyard Kipling, that appears on the graves of unidentified soldiers for which no details are known is " A Soldier of the Great War known unto God ". Some headstones bear the text " believed to be buried in this cemetery " when they are believed to be buried in the cemetery but the exact location of the grave is not known. In some cases soldiers were buried in collective graves and distinguishing one body from another was not possible and thus one headstone covers more than one grave. The headstone does not denote any specific details of the death except for its date, and even then only if it is known, and are deliberately ambiguous about the cause of death.

In the 19th century, flowers were used as a way of commemorating the dead, as well as for decorative purposes. However, by the end of the 1800s, flowers were seen as a waste of money and, as a result, many cemeteries began to turn to other means of memorializing the dead. These methods included planting and caring for flowers, or burying the flowers in vases or urns.

Flowering shrubs and perennials such as poppies, hydrangeas, dahlias, lantillias, tulips, violets, geraniums, and peonies are common in cemetery floral arrangements. These types of flowers have the ability to survive for a long time without water, and are easy to care for in the event of a grave being vandalized, which is a common occurrence these days.
